articles.headline: ‘Making a Murderer’ Town’s Answer to Netflix Series: You Don’t Know
articles.snippet: A reporter goes back to Manitowoc County, Wis., where residents who considered the 10-year-old case settled are being second-guessed about Steven Avery’s return to prison.
articles.abstract: A reporter goes back to Manitowoc County, Wis., where residents who considered the 10-year-old case settled are being second-guessed about Steven Avery’s return to prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANITOWOC, Wis. — In the tourism office here, where workers are accustomed to cheery inquiries about Manitowoc County’s best jogging paths and beach views, the questions have suddenly turned dark: How could you possibly promote tourism in such a corrupt town? Why would anyone visit here?

articles.headline: In Iowa, Jobs Are Plentiful but Workers Are Not
articles.snippet: Employers across Iowa, whose jobless rate is only 3.4 percent, lament that the state has “run out of people for jobs.”
articles.abstract: Employers across Iowa, whose jobless rate is only 3.4 percent, lament that the state has “run out of people for jobs.”
articles.lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — Unlike the indoor basketball court, foosball tables or fireside lounge at Workiva’s sprawling campus here, the oversize green prize wheel centered among a hive of work stations is not meant for break times.

articles.headline: Justices Take On a Muddled Issue: Insider Trading
articles.snippet: If the Supreme Court upholds a conviction in a case from California, it could provide guidelines on the requirement of proof that a defendant in such cases sought personal gain.
articles.abstract: If the Supreme Court upholds a conviction in a case from California, it could provide guidelines on the requirement of proof that a defendant in such cases sought personal gain.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 30 years since I chronicled the 1980s insider trading scandals in the book “Den of Thieves,” I’ve never seen the insider trading law in a greater state of confusion.

articles.headline: Politico Will Lose Its Co-Founder and 4 Others
articles.snippet: Jim VandeHei and Mike Allen will leave the political publication later this year, along with others, shaking up a rapidly expanding organization.
articles.abstract: Jim VandeHei and Mike Allen will leave the political publication later this year, along with others, shaking up a rapidly expanding organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Politico co-founder and chief executive, Jim VandeHei, and one of its best-known journalists, Mike Allen, plan to leave the publication after the November presidential election, its owner Robert Allbritton said in a memo to the staff on Thursday. Three other senior executives also plan to leave.

articles.headline: Xerox Planning Spinoff, Under Pressure From Carl Icahn
articles.snippet: The company is said to have agreed to spin off its services business to its shareholders by the end of the year, separating it from the legacy hardware side.
articles.abstract: The company is said to have agreed to spin off its services business to its shareholders by the end of the year, separating it from the legacy hardware side.
articles.lead_paragraph: Another American corporate icon has decided that breaking up is the thing to do.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Liz Moyer

articles.headline: More Is Needed to Beat ISIS, Pentagon Officials Conclude
articles.snippet: To deal a lasting blow to the extremist Sunni militancy, officials believe that additional forces will be needed to work with Iraqi, Kurdish and Syrian opposition fighters.
articles.abstract: To deal a lasting blow to the extremist Sunni militancy, officials believe that additional forces will be needed to work with Iraqi, Kurdish and Syrian opposition fighters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pentagon officials have concluded that hundreds more trainers, advisers and commandos from the United States and its allies will need to be sent to Iraq and Syria in the coming months as the campaign to isolate the Islamic State intensifies.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Clash Harshly, Filling Void on G.O.P. Debate Stage
articles.snippet: The final Republican debate before the Iowa caucuses took a surreal turn as seven candidates found their messages overshadowed by Donald J. Trump’s boycott of the event.
articles.abstract: The final Republican debate before the Iowa caucuses took a surreal turn as seven candidates found their messages overshadowed by Donald J. Trump’s boycott of the event.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The Republican presidential candidates competed vigorously to fill the vacuum created by Donald J. Trump’s boycott of Thursday night’s debate, with Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida trading ferocious attacks on immigration and taking fire from rivals seeking advantage in the Iowa caucuses on Monday.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Bank of Japan, in a Surprise, Adopts Negative Interest Rate
articles.snippet: The central bank will charge commercial depositors to hold money in its vaults — a move meant to stimulate the economy amid global market turmoil.
articles.abstract: The central bank will charge commercial depositors to hold money in its vaults — a move meant to stimulate the economy amid global market turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Japan’s economic doldrums have lingered, its leaders have tried a number of tricks over the years, from increasing government spending to flooding the financial system with cash.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Takes to Solo Stage Instead of G.O.P. Debate
articles.snippet: It was supposed to be about the veterans. It was not really about the veterans.
articles.abstract: It was supposed to be about the veterans. It was not really about the veterans.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — It was supposed to be about the veterans.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Drug Shortages Forcing Hard Decisions on Rationing Treatments
articles.snippet: Such shortages are the new normal in American medicine. But the rationing that results has been largely hidden from patients and the public.
articles.abstract: Such shortages are the new normal in American medicine. But the rationing that results has been largely hidden from patients and the public.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In the operating room at the Cleveland Clinic, Dr. Brian Fitzsimons has long relied on a decades-old drug to prevent hemorrhages in patients undergoing open-heart surgery. The drug, aminocaproic acid, is widely used, cheap and safe. “It never hurt,” he said. “It only helps.”

articles.headline: Israel, Mired in Ideological Battles, Fights on Cultural Fronts
articles.snippet: A “Loyalty in Culture” initiative, included as an amendment to a budget bill, proposes denying state funds to institutions that do not express “loyalty” to the state.
articles.abstract: A “Loyalty in Culture” initiative, included as an amendment to a budget bill, proposes denying state funds to institutions that do not express “loyalty” to the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — There have been fights over books, music, plays, funding for the arts and academic awards. This being Israel, they have been underpinned by fierce rhetorical exchanges about democracy, fascism and zealotry, identity, the future of the state and the fate of Jews.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Barely Grew Last Quarter, Stoking Concerns About Momentum in 2016
articles.snippet: The economy is facing headwinds like turmoil in global markets, but the job and housing markets remain strong.
articles.abstract: The economy is facing headwinds like turmoil in global markets, but the job and housing markets remain strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy finished the year on a flat note, much as it started 2015, stoking concern about its vulnerability in the months ahead to turmoil in China and elsewhere in the global economy.

articles.headline: Cutting Off Those Recurring Charges You Forgot About
articles.snippet: A new service promises to ferret out those monthly billings for services you forgot you signed up for, and put a stop to them.
articles.abstract: A new service promises to ferret out those monthly billings for services you forgot you signed up for, and put a stop to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you want newly invented ice cream flavors to show up at your home each month, you can get a subscription for that.

articles.headline: Flint Weighs Scope of Harm to Children Caused by Lead in Water
articles.snippet: As officials try to track how many children in Flint, Mich., have been exposed to lead, underlying troubles prevalent among low-income families add to concerns.
articles.abstract: As officials try to track how many children in Flint, Mich., have been exposed to lead, underlying troubles prevalent among low-income families add to concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — Quayana Towns’s 2-month-old daughter wriggled on an exam table last week as her pediatrician ticked off questions that have become essential for every parent of young children here.
